I20031119 (M5 test pass)

1. have this code:

public class Test {
	
	public void foobar() {
		class Listener3 {
			private Test fTest;
			
			private Listener3() {
				fTest= Test.this;
			}
		}
		
		this.addListener(new Listener3() {
			public int bar() {
				return 1;
			}
		});
	}
	
	
	public void addListener(Object o) {
	}

}

2. Select the expression ("Test.this") assigned to the field "test" in the local
type's ctor
3. Choose Refactor->Introduce Parameter
4. In the dialog that shows, accept the default and press OK
-> AssertionFailedException, stack trace follows:

Is anyone working on this? I've looked into it
a bit and would try to fix it -- just making
sure I'm not duplicating an effort.

I'm new to Eclipse and would appreciate
any pointers to information on the structure
of the JDT code (other than the API Reference
and the JDT Plug-in Developer Guide). I've
figured a lot of things out by perusing the
code, but a systematic exposition would help.
Specifically, I didn't find anything about the
relationships between DOM and JDOM, "old" and
"new" ASTs, and bindings and source elements.

I'm not actively working on this for the next two weeks -- a quality patch would
be welcome.

Unfortunately, we don't have more documents on the structure of JDT -- it's all
in the source. But the basic structure is simple:

- The IJavaElement hierarchy in org.eclipse.jdt.core provides lightweight
handles for java language elements down to the member level. They are used as
references in search and UI and they're persistable.

- org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom holds an AST, which can be created per compilation
unit. Bindings are the compiler's view on identifiers - if two bindings are
equal, then they stand for the "same thing".

- The org.eclipse.jdt.core.jdom thing is old and I've never used that
*** Bug 47547 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
